content.description:
The best route at this quirky micro crag. The first line you get to when you hike in. It follows the prominent arete feature but involves mostly face climbing to the right of the arete. 

  Steep moves off the ground won't feel as hard if you hit it just right. There are however a few enticing sucker holds. At the half way point you hit a cruxy steep move to gain the crimpy but less difficult upper face. 

  The top is covered in lichen so i didn't bother topping out.
content.protection: 4 bolts, no anchor. You could anchor to the trees above.
content.location: The left most bolted line at the crag.

content.description:
The right hand line at this cliff. Super crimpy and a bit pumpy for its short length. Though it's most often wet I thought it had some fun climbing on it if you like crimping down hard. If it was dry it might get a star and a half. be careful of some looseish holds near the bottom. 

  Topping out wouldn't be hard if it was dry but you can clean your draws off of the fixed biner on the last bolt if you don't.
content.protection: 4 bolts, no anchor. could belay from the trees.
content.location: The right hand bolted route at the bakery.

climbs.name: Mr Mailman
climbs.fa: Lee Hansche and Torie Kidd, April 2019

content.description:
Every time I'd walked by this obviuos steep crack in it's v-groove Chimney I've had some reason why I didn't doit that day. No trad gear with me, wettness, other priorities but the other day it was just wet and dirty enough I thought it was finally the right time haha. 

 With dry weather and a bit of cleaning I really think it will be a nice climb, If a bitshort. 

 Climb up on to a ledge, place a solid piece and ooze your way in to the groove above. A splitter crack runs all the way up the corner. This might be one of the most traight forward cracks to place gear on in Rumneyalong with Blackjack and Very Nice Crack.
content.protection: Regular rack. Belay and rappel from the trees.
content.location: This one starts around the left side of the bakery just left of Sport Moves.

content.description:
I climbed this one today at last and I must say that it was dirty but i rapped in to give it a quick cleaning and realized quickly that if it wasn't wet 11 months of the year this would be quite a nice route.  

  between the 2 sport routes there is a left angling crack with a bolt low down (the book said 2 bolts but there is just one). The crack is choked with moss and dirt and is normally really wet. 

  if you find it dry, and want to have a go. Give it a quick brush down then. follow a wandering path of nice crimps past the bolt and surprisingly decent gear you can't see from below.
content.protection: Small gear and a few draws, anchor at the trees above.

content.description:
A small collection of routes on a little cliff band that is plagued by wetness most of the year. There are many reasons not to climb here, wet rock, moss, lichen, loose rocks, short routes, no anchors. the fact that it is very close to and overlooking somebody's house, etc. There is only one reason to climb here, Sport Moves 5.11a, its not classic but fun none the less. 

  The strangest thing about The Bakery is that the well bolted routes here don't have 2 bolt anchors. As of now there is a fixed biner on the last bolt of each route and i just used those biners to clean them.  

  In the old guide book mentions that The Bakery may be on private land so if you choose to climb here keep a low profile.
